nitf_Version nitf_Reader_getNITFVersion ( const char *  fileName  ) 

Return the NITFVersion of the file passed in by its file name. This is a static method (not associated with a specific Reader).

Parameters:
fileName The name of the file to check
Returns:
NITFVersion of the file

nitf_ImageReader* nitf_Reader_newImageReader ( nitf_Reader *  reader,
int  imageSegmentNumber,
nitf_Error *  error 
)

This creates a new ImageReader object that can be used to access the data in the image segment. This should be done after the read() function has been called and a record loaded.

The ImageReader object is a specialized reader for dealing with images. It is provided by the library, and should almost always be used when reading images.

Parameters:
reader The reader object
imageSegmentNumber The index
error A populated error if return value is zero
Returns:
new nitf_ImageReader* for the image in question

nitf_SegmentReader* nitf_Reader_newTextReader ( nitf_Reader *  reader,

Returns:

nitf_Record* nitf_Reader_read ( nitf_Reader *  reader,
nitf_IOHandle  inputHandle,
nitf_Error *  error 
)

This is the method for reading information from a NITF (or NSIF). It reads all of the support data, including TREs, which it parses if it knows of the appropriate location. The output is a record of the information in the NITF.

After this operation is completed, a user will typically create a new ImageReader using the method in this class in order to read the imagery from an appropriate sub-window.

Parameters:
reader The reader object
io The file io
error A populated error if return value is zero
Returns:
A dynamically allocated record pointing to the internal support data in the NITF file

nitf_Record* nitf_Reader_readIO ( nitf_Reader *  reader,
nitf_IOInterface *  io,
nitf_Error *  error 
)

Same as the read function, except this method allows you to change the underlying interface. The read method calls this one using an IOInterface adaptor
